title: Oil Consumption / Leaks
description: Diagnose oil leaks and excessive oil consumption on the Kymco Like 125i scooter.

nodes.text: How is the oil issue presenting on your Like 125i?

options.text: Visible oil dripping or pooling under the scooter
Oil level drops between changes but no visible leak
Oil weeping from engine (wet but not dripping)

nodes.instructions: Clean the engine with degreaser. Run for a few minutes, then inspect with a flashlight. Oil runs downward, so the source is above the drip. Common leak spots on the Like 125i: (1) Oil drain plug, (2) Valve cover gasket, (3) Crankcase seams, (4) Crankshaft seals (left/right), (5) Oil filter screen cap.

nodes.text: Where is the oil coming from?

nodes.instructions: Check: (1) Is the plug tight? Torque to 20-25 Nm, (2) Is the crush washer in place and undamaged? (3) Are threads stripped from over-tightening? The drain plug on the Like 125i is on the bottom of the crankcase.

nodes.text: What is the drain plug condition?

nodes.instructions: If oil disappears without external leaks, the engine is burning it. Check: (1) Blue/grey exhaust smoke (especially during acceleration/deceleration), (2) Oily residue at the exhaust tip, (3) Oil-fouled spark plug, (4) Oil in the air filter box (indicates crankcase breather issue or blow-by from worn rings).

nodes.text: What signs of burning did you find?

options.text: No visible smoke but oil drops

nodes.text: Determine if valve seals or piston rings
nodes.warning: Both conditions benefit from professional diagnosis.
nodes.instructions: Valve seal wear: smoke mainly on startup or deceleration. Ring wear: smoke under acceleration, continuous, with low compression. Do a compression test — Like 125i should produce 10-12 bar (145-175 PSI). Low compression + smoke = rings. Normal compression + smoke on decel = valve seals.
Look for oil residue along gasket seams: (1) Valve cover gasket — most common, (2) Cylinder base gasket, (3) Crankcase cover gaskets. Weeping attracts dirt and looks messy but may not drip.

nodes.action: Tightened the drain plug. Clean area and monitor.
nodes.details: Torque to 20-25 Nm. Use a torque wrench. Do not overtighten.

nodes.action: Replace the drain plug crush washer.
nodes.details: Replace at every oil change. Reused washers leak. These are inexpensive — keep spares on hand.

nodes.warning: Stripped threads worsen if not repaired. Do not use oversized bolts as a fix.
nodes.action: Install a thread repair insert (Helicoil or similar).
nodes.details: Drill, tap, and install a threaded insert. Keep metal chips out of the crankcase. Alternatively, use an oversize drain plug with a rubber seal as a temporary fix.
Easy and inexpensive repair. Clean both surfaces. Tighten bolts evenly in a cross pattern (10-12 Nm). Good time to check valve clearances.

nodes.warning: Splitting crankcase halves requires full engine disassembly — advanced repair.
nodes.action: If the leak is at the crankcase mating surface, the gasket has failed.
nodes.details: Minor weeping can be monitored. Significant leaks require splitting the cases — this is usually done during a major overhaul.

nodes.warning: Requires flywheel or CVT variator removal. Use proper puller tools.
nodes.action: Replace the leaking crankshaft oil seal.
nodes.details: Pry out old seal carefully, press new seal in squarely. Apply oil to the seal lip before installation. Intermediate repair requiring a flywheel puller.

nodes.text: Use UV Dye to Find Leak
nodes.action: Add UV dye to the oil and use a UV light to find the leak.
nodes.details: Run the engine for 15-20 minutes, then inspect with a UV flashlight. The dye glows brightly at leak points. Safe for use in engine oil.

nodes.action: Clean or replace the crankcase breather valve and hose.
nodes.details: Oil in the air box indicates breather issues or excessive blow-by from worn rings. Clean the breather system first. If the problem recurs, compression test the engine — low compression means worn rings.

nodes.action: Replace the intake and exhaust valve stem seals.
nodes.details: Remove the head, use a valve spring compressor to access seals. Check valve guides for wear — new seals on worn guides won't solve the problem.

nodes.action: Rebuild the top end with new piston rings.
nodes.details: Remove head and cylinder. Measure bore for wear. Light hone and new rings if within spec. Re-bore with oversize piston if worn. Replace valve seals and head gasket at the same time.

nodes.warning: Requires removing the head and cylinder.
nodes.details: Clean mating surfaces with a plastic scraper. Inspect piston and rings while cylinder is off.
Remove cover bolts, separate, clean surfaces, install new gasket. Some covers use liquid gasket sealant — apply in a thin, even bead. Allow curing time before adding oil.
